abstract: Actors' Equity, union representing some 6,500 stage actors in Los Angeles, faces rift with many of its own members as it seeks to seize on national shifts in minimum wage debate; union is pushing theaters to pay actors state minimum wage of $9 an hour, but many members say they are willing to continue working for a pittance, fearing that theaters will fail financially and deprive them of chance to hone their craft.
lead_paragraph: The willingness of Los Angeles actors to perform for a pittance is at the heart of a rift in the Actors’ Equity union, which represents theater actors.

headline.main: Actors’ Equity Pushes for Minimum Wage, but Not All Members Want It
headline.print_headline: Union Pushes for a Minimum Wage, but Not All Its Actors Want It

snippet: The willingness of Los Angeles actors to perform for a pittance is at the heart of a rift in the Actors’ Equity union, which represents theater actors.
